Today we all celebrate #Juneteenth. It commemorates the reading of the Emancipation Proclamation declaring all slaves free in Galveston, Texas two years after the official proclamation. On this day, we are reminded of our ugly history of slavery and how we have still not corrected the failings of our past. ECS is committed to becoming an anti-racist institution in which our black students and student of color are seen, heard, and valued. We acknowledge that it is on all of us to do the work to fight systemic inequities. As a parent/guardian, you may be wondering where to start. Here are some resources to help you along your journey.

post_text: Mary Miss is an environmental artist and a pioneer of the land-art movement. Miss received her B.A. in art in 1966 from the University of California, Santa Barbara, and an M.F.A from the Maryland Institute College of Art in 1968. Her works are interdisciplinary and informed by the history and ecology of the settings in which her installations reside. In 2009, Miss encouraged artists to collaborate with scientists, planners, and other experts to create place-based artwork that could engage the public with the environment and issues of sustainability. This was a part of her City as Living Laboratory (CaLL) initiative. To learn more about Mary Miss and her contributions to environmental art, go to https://tclf.org/pioneer/mary-miss. (All information and photos were taken from the above website.) #WomensHistoryMonth

post_text: Winona LaDuke grew up in Los Angeles, California, and she credits her parents for her activism spirit. LaDuke graduated from Harvard with a bachelor's degree in native economic development, and she went on to work internationally on issues of sustainable development, renewable energy, climate change, food systems, and environmental justice with Indigenous communities. LaDuke is also the founder of one of the largest reservation-based nonprofit organizations in the country, the White Earth Land Recovery Project. In 2007, LaDuke was recognized for her leadership and commitment to her community by being inducted into the National Women's Hall of Fame, and she is widely known for her work with environmental and human rights issues. To learn more about Winona LaDuke, go to http://www.honorearth.org/speaking_engagements. (All information was taken from the link above.) #WomensHistoryMonth

post_text: #FieldTrip This past Monday (3/9/20), E-Day students went on their first after-school field trip to Oasis Farm & Fishery. Farmer Tacumba led a tour and instructed Better Food Better Me, a farm-to-plate cooking class. The students worked together to gain new insights and skills as they made Tikil Gomen, a popular dish from Ethiopian cuisine featuring potatoes, carrots, onions, herbs, and spices. Thank you Oasis Farm & Fishery for helping ECS #GrowCitizens!

post_text: Wangari Maathai founded the Green Belt Movement in Africa. Born in 1940, Maathai earned a degree in Biological Sciences from Mount St. Scholastica College, a Master of Science degree from the University of Pittsburgh, and a Ph.D. from the University of Nairobi. Maathai was the first woman in East and Central Africa to earn a doctorate degree, and she later became the chair of the Department of Veterinary Anatomy and an associate professor. She was the first woman to hold both of those positions in the region. Learn more about Wangari Maathai and her environmental work at https://www.greenbeltmovement.org/wangari-maathai. (All information was taken from the above website.) #WomensHistoryMonth

post_text: Dr. Robert Bullard documented Environmental Racism for more than 40 years. Bullard became interested in environmental racism when his wife, an attorney, represented members of a black middle-class community who were fighting against a landfill being in their suburban neighborhood. Inspired to learn more about communities of color facing pollution burdens, Bullard went on to conduct his own research and present his findings in 18 books while being coined "the father of environmental justice" along the way. To learn more about Dr. Robert Bullard and his research, go to https://therevelator.org/bullard-environmental-justice/. (All information, including the photo, was taken from the above website.) #BlackHistoryMonth #EnvironmentalJustice

Her research extended well after graduating, and Daly became committed to creating programs to increase enrollment of minority students in the medical school and graduate science programs. post_text: #DidYouKnow Colonel Charles Young was a soldier, diplomat, civil rights leader, and the first African-American National Park Superintendent. Born to enslaved parents in 1864 during the Civil War, Charles excelled in academics, foreign languages, and music. Young went on to have an active military career, and in 1903, he and his troops were assigned to manage and maintain the Sequoia National Park in California making him the first African-American National Park Superintendent. Young developed roads and trails throughout the park, some of which are still used today. To learn more about Colonel Charles Young, go to https://www.nps.gov/chyo/learn/historyculture/colonel-charles-young.htm. (Picture and information were taken from the above link.) #BlackHistoryMonth

Born to enslaved parents in 1864 during the Civil War, Charles excelled in academics, foreign languages, and music. Young went on to have an active military career, and in 1903, he and his troops were assigned to manage and maintain the Sequoia National Park in California making him the first African-American National Park Superintendent. Young developed roads and trails throughout the park, some of which are still used today. The ECS Middle School is looking for Biking Volunteers!

The 6th-grade Physical Education classes participate in a biking program called Bike ECS. Students learn about gears, brakes, riding signals, bike safety, quick checks, and how to ride as a group off-campus. This program needs more volunteers to ride with us and to also stay on campus and help our new bike riders master their skills. BikeEcs time is from 12:20-1:15 daily during our 6th grade PE times.

Interested in being a part of our program, learning more, or helping with bike maintenance or riding? Please contact Mrs. Moore at clare.moore@ecspgh.org. A stipend will be provided to those who volunteer.

Online Safety: Be Proactive!
Screen time continues to be a question that parents/guardians grapple with. There are various opinions and resources to help guide your decisions as a caretaker --ultimately, you need to do what is best for your family. In addition to screen time decisions, preserving and promoting quality sleep time can also be a place to start in the building overall health and wellness of your child.

Discuss the need for quality sleep at night, charging electronics in common areas (not in bedrooms), and shutting down electronics at least thirty minutes before bedtime. Check out this article for more info!
